awd_titl_txt: Quantification and Reduction of Spatial Scale-Induced Uncertainty
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will examine spatial scale-induced uncertainties and address issues involved in assembling multi-source, multi-scale data in a spatial analysis.  Many spatial studies are compromised due to a discrepancy between the spatial scale at which data are analyzed and the spatial scale at which the phenomenon under investigation operates.  One consequence has been that research findings often conflict when analyses are conducted at differing scales.  Decision making and policy formulation therefore may be misguided by conflicting, biased research findings brought about by spatial scale.  Lacking appropriate ways to deal with this spatial problem has made many existing findings less compelling or even invalid.  In the era of big data with the advancement of spatial data collection technologies, data that were once difficult or impossible to obtain are now widely available at various spatial scales and are being used to study a variety of problems.  Questions regarding spatial data thus become more pressing.  The strategies to be developed for addressing the spatial scale issues have the potential to be applied to many fields and applications.  The research results will benefit researchers and practitioners in processing, analyzing, and presenting multi-source, multi-scale spatial data. 

Numerous studies have been conducted to understand how issues related to scale influence analyses and interpretation. Despite the efforts, this remains a widely recognized, complex problem with few generalizable solutions.  Even when studies are conducted at the appropriate spatial scale, uncertainty may exist because data are usually collected at different scales and therefore must be aggregated or interpolated to achieve the study scale.  Using a large public health surveillance dataset, the investigators will develop a measurement error-based statistical framework to quantify the space scale-induced uncertainties and provide strategies to ameliorate the issues.  The research will address issues of 1) characterization of scale due to spatial scale definition and data misalignment in the measurement error framework; 2) quantification of the effects of scale issues on the estimation significance and parameter biasedness; and 3) strategies that may be used to reduce uncertainties in a multi-scale analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Many spatial studies are compromised due to a discrepancy between the spatial scale at which the data are analyzed and the spatial scale at which the phenomenon under investigation operates. Among others, one consequence has been that research findings often conflict when analyses are conducted at differing scales. As a result, decision making and policy formulation can be misguided by conflicting, biased research findings brought about by spatial scale. Although numerous studies have been conducted to understand the uncertainties introduced by spatial scale, it remains a widely recognized complex problem in terms of how spatial scale influence analysis results with few generalizable solutions. To help address this issue, this project focused on quantification of spatial-scale induced uncertainties and development of strategies to mitigate the impacts.

 

The project includes both theoretical and applied work to examine issues related to spatial scale. The theoretical work (1) examined how spatial scale and aggregation affect spatial variable construction such as distance and distance-based accessibility measures; (2) investigated how alternative ways of space abstraction affect model accuracy and performance; (3) analyzed the measurement error (Berkson error and classical error) in spatial variable construction; (4) constructed a new (unbiased) distance metric for measuring area-to-point distance to account for spatial data aggregation and developed a new algorithm to compute the new distance metric in an efficient fashion; (5) explored new approaches to incorporate spatial data uncertainty and robustness into spatial data visualization, such as choropleth mapping.

 

The applied work examined valley fever (VF) risk assessment in Arizona. Risk factors associated with valley fever were identified, including demographic and socioeconomic data (population, income, age) at the three scales (census block, block group and tract), soil property, wetland, desert and land cover. Empirical analysis were conducted to examine how spatial scale and data aggregation affect factors associated with VF. Another empirical study focused on distance based food access evaluation. Analysis results showed that the scale effect can operate differently on different neighborhoods. In particular, food access for low-income neighborhoods is very likely overestimated based on the current census tract level measurement. Given that government funding and assistance programs are largely allocated based on food deserts identified at the census tract level, it is probable that many  low-income people are being left unserved or under-served.

Both theoretical and applied research show that spatial uncertainty introduced in a statistical model may be related to both the amount of spatial separation and the scale of the spatial units used to aggregate individual observations. In particular, when individuals are aggregated into areal units, such as census block groups and tracts, it was shown that measuring distances from areas/polygons based on their centers/centroids or representative points lead to biased estimates. High bias is associated with objects in close spatial proximity or of a large size. To mitigate such bias, an unbiased distance metric was developed along with a algorithm to compute the new distance more efficiently.

During the project period, new classification schemes have been developed to incorporate uncertain spatial data and analysis results into data visualization through choropleth mapping. In particular, a new classification scheme was developed to minimize within-class deviation when spatial data to be presented contain uncertainty. Different methods, including mixed integer programming, dynamic programming, and an interchange heuristic were examined to solve the new classification problem. It has been shown that the classic classification scheme, Jenks natural breaks, is a special case of the new classification scheme when uncertainty is normally distributed and variances are the same for all spatial units. Building on the new classification scheme, another new choropleth mapping approach was developed to account for robustness. A robustness measure was constructed and incorporated into the optimal design of choropleth maps. A discretization based method was proposed to solve the new optimization problem along with a novel theoretical bound for solution quality evaluation. The research offers a new approach for spatial analysts and decision makers to incorporate robustness into visualization of uncertain spatial data.

The research results have been shared with practitioners and scholars at local public health agencies and national and international conferences in geography, public health and engineering. The models and approaches developed for quantifying, mitigating and visualizing the uncertainties associated with spatial scale can be to be applied to studies in many other fields. The project also provides a unique opportunity to develop collaboration among researchers in geography, statistics, engineering and epidemiology and support the training of students in these disciplines. In addition to research presentations at conferences, workshops and seminars, the research has resulted in one dissertation, six journal articles published or accepted for publication, and two manuscripts submitted for publication consideration.
